chapter.title: Welcome
chapter.para: Welcome to the manual for GrandOrgue.

listitem.para: Click the Contents tab to display a list of important topics about the program.
Click the Index tab to display an alphabetical listing of topics.
Click the Search tab to search for a specific word in the help system.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: GrandOrgue allows the user to load and play virtual pipe organs. Using sample sets, GrandOrgue is able to combine the individual pipe sounds and organ behaviours to simulate a variety of pipe organs.

sect1.title: Sample Sets
sect1.para: GrandOrgue is capable of loading and faithfully reproducing a variety of sample sets. Through extensive testing, it appears highly compatible with definition files that have worked in Hauptwerk™ version 1. Other types of sample sets may also be compatible, and other formats may soon be available. As such, you won't be able to do anything at all with GrandOrgue without at least one sample set. Sample sets generally come packaged or with installers. By default, the software loads organs from "My Organs" in your documents folder, but you may store sample sets wherever is convenient and space permits.

sect1.title: Volume Control
sect1.para: The volume control sets the volume control as a percentage of full volume. Note that this is percentage of voltage, and therefore every half corresponds to -6dB. That is, 50% is -6dB, 25% is -12dB, etc. To the right of the spinner are the left and right audio monitors, respectively. The clip indicator at the far right will turn red if clipping occurs, and will stay red until the volume is adjusted.

sect1.title: Polyphony Control
sect1.para: The polyphony control sets the maximum polyphony before GrandOrgue will refuse to play any additional samples. To oversimplify, polyphony is the number of pipes that may sound simultaneously; but polyphony may also be consumed when a key is released. It is recommended to experiment with this setting initially, but leave it once you find an acceptable setting. Your setting should balance between too little polyphony (where you might not be able to play many notes on large sample sets) and too much polyphony (where the CPU will overload and artifacts will appear in the sound). Note that "wet" sample sets (those with considerable reverberation) will consume polyphony many seconds after the note is actually released. The default setting of 1024 should provide a reasonable starting point on a 1GHz CPU. To the right of the spinner is the polyphony monitor. The clip indicator at the far right will turn red if the polyphony limit has been reached, and will stay red until the polyphony is adjusted.

sect1.title: Program Changes
sect1.para: The spinner sets the current program number. This might be termed a "sequencer" on modern computerized organs. It is possible to store up to 512 organ states and access them sequentially via the predefined MIDI events, or access any setting directly through the spinner. You may also use the left and right keys on the keyboard to scroll through the programs, and down to reactivate the current program (if you have changed the stops since last activating it, for example). Note also that when memory set is engaged, the target program wil be stored to, i.e. if you push Shift + Right then the program would be advanced and the current settings would be saved to this same next program.

sect1.title: Manuals
sect1.para: Each manual as well as the pedalboard is displayed in the center of the screen. The keys are outlined when messages are received, but may not be engaged by clicking the mouse. Right clicking on a manual will open its corresponding MIDI Event Editor.

sect1.title: Expression Pedals
sect1.para: Directly above the pedalboard are displayed the pedals, sometimes referred to as "swell pedals", although they may control any of the manuals (Great, Swell, Wonderful, etc). On a pipe organ, swell shutters dampen the sound, and this is simulated in GrandOrgue by adjusting the volume of the enclosed pipes. While the mouse is over a pedal, you may use the mouse wheel to adjust its position, or right click to open its corresponding MIDI Event Editor.

sect1.title: Drawstops
sect1.para: The drawstops engage or disengage various components of the organ when clicked - generally new ranks of pipes which are applied to each manual. Other drawstops may perform actions such as coupling one manual to another. This deals with the functionality of pipe organs and is beyond the scope of this documentation. Right clicking on a drawstop will open its corresponding MIDI Event Editor. Any changes made there may be saved in the organ definition file or settings files.

sect1.title: Pistons
sect1.para: Pistons generally perform an action when clicked and do not have an on/off toggle, although some pistons may toggle in this way. Pistons often recall drawstop combinations, and when used in combination with the Memory Set, you can store your own combinations in the pistons. Right clicking on a piston will open its corresponding MIDI Event Editor. Any changes made there may be saved in the organ definition file or settings files.

chapter.title: File Menu
chapter.para: The File menu contains commands for dealing with the loading and saving of sample sets.

sect1.title: Open
sect1.para: Import a sample set stored in a definition file. The location will be remembered for the next open operation. The most recently used sample sets are also remembered and available in the "Import Recent" popup. Loading sample sets takes some time; a progress window will display indicating estimated time remaining and other indicators. If you open a new sample set which shares samples with the previously loaded sample set, those files are cached and will not be reloaded from disk.

sect1.title: Reload
sect1.para: Reload the currently loaded sample set from disk. This may be used to quickly restore a sample set to its saved status, for example if a settings file has been applied.

sect1.title: Reset to Defaults
sect1.para: Reset the currently loaded sample set to the settings as originally supplied by the sample set provider. You will be asked to verify that you wish to discard your modifications. Note that these settings are stored at the end of the definition file and could be easily removed with a text editor as well if necessary.

sect1.title: Import Settings
sect1.para: Apply a settings file to the currently loaded sample set. Note that settings may only be applied to a matching sample set, and you will receive a warning if you try to do otherwise. The location will be remembered for the next time, independently of other saved locations.

sect1.title: Export Settings
sect1.para: Save a settings file including the stop and piston MIDI messages; stop engaged states; divisional, general, and program combinations; and the volume.

sect1.title: Update Cache
sect1.para: Save the loaded and processed samples to the hard disk. Doing so decreases loading time at the expense of hard disk space. Selecting this option displays a message indicating how much space is required and confirming that you would like to proceed. If compression is disabled, load speed only increases by 10 to 15%. However, with compression enabled, the load time when using the sample cache may be cut by 40% or more.

Note that different load settings or tunings each require their own cache file. For example, stereo compressed samples and mono uncompressed samples each need their own cache. It is therefore recommended that you limit your cache updates to one particular load type (preferably stereo compressed, as this is the recommended setting).

sect1.title: Save
sect1.para: Save to the definition file: the stop and piston MIDI messages; stop engaged states; divisional, general, and program combinations; and the volume. Note that this is completely reversible using the Reset to Defaults option, and is the recommend method for most users.

sect1.title: Close
sect1.para: Close the currently loaded sample set. If you have made any settings changes, you will be asked if you would like to save them before the sample set closes. Note that this will also unload the sample set and free the RAM it required.

sect1.title: Properties
sect1.para: This window displays various characteristics of the loaded sample set as provided by the sample set producer. If available, there is also a link to "More Information" which will open additional information in another application.

chapter.title: Audio Menu
chapter.para: The Audio menu contains commands for dealing with loaded organs and associated settings.

sect1.title: Record
sect1.para: Opens a dialog prompting where to save the recorded WAV file. The location will be remembered for the next time, independently of other saved locations. Upon clicking selecting a file name, recording commences and continues until the Record menu option or toolbar button is selected again. A checkmark appears next to the menu item, and the toolbar button remains pushed, to indicate when recording is active.

sect1.title: Memory Set
sect1.para: Enters memory set mode until the Memory Set menu option or toolbar button is selected again. While the memory set is engaged, whenever you push a divisional or general piston or activate a program change, the organ will store the current settings to that piston or program change rather than recalling them. For example, engaging a divisional piston 1 during memory set will store the state of stops for that manual into piston 1, which could then be pushed later (after memory set has been disengaged) to recall those stops. A checkmark appears next to the menu item, and the toolbar button remains pushed, to indicate when memory set is active.

sect1.title: Panic
sect1.para: The effect of the panic button is to reset the sound, stopping all sound and turning off all notes. It may also be quickly accessed on the toolbar or via the Escape key. This should be generally unnecessary, although it may be useful if you need to quickly stop the sound output, or if the sound is breaking up due to CPU overload.

sect1.title: Settings
sect1.para: Displays a tabbed dialog containg the audio settings. For more information, refer to the Device Settings and MIDI Settings sections.

sect1.title: Index
sect1.para: Opens this help document. Pressing F1 at other locations in the program will jump directly to the appropriate topic.

sect1.title: About
sect1.para: Displays the splash screen.

sect1.title: MIDI Messages
sect1.para: This screen lists all of the MIDI actions which GrandOrgue can respond to. The "Action" column describes the action; the "Event" column shows the MIDI event it is currently tied to; the "Channel" column indicates which channel the action will listen on, if any; the "Data" column indicates the specific data which will trigger the action - for example, a controller number or a program change number. These actions may be modified by selecting the action and clicking "Properties", or by double-clicking on the action.

sect1.title: MIDI Event Properties
sect1.para: This displays the MIDI event editor dialog. You may select an event from the drop-down box (only available events will be shown), or you may select "(none)" to disable the action. The channel spinner sets the channel tied ot the MIDI message, and the data spinner (when applicable) selects the data tied to the MIDI message. For easy configuration, click "Listen for Event" and then perform the desired MIDI action (i.e. push a note on the appropriate keyboard, do a program change, flip a MIDI switch, etc). If the performed MIDI event is allowed for this action, its data is filled in and the "Listen for Event" button is deactivated. You may also manually deactivate the listener by clicking on it again. Be sure to select OK to save your changes when you're done.

sect1.title: MIDI Input Devices
sect1.para: A list of all MIDI input interfaces available. Selecting a device means that GrandOrgue will listen for incoming MIDI messages on through that interface. This allows to listen to more than one device at a time; for example, to listen to both a controller and a sequencer or loopback device.

sect1.title: Advanced
sect1.para: Either select a device and click Advanced, or double click on the device. This brings up a window that allows the setting of a channel offset. A channel offset allows the use of two MIDI interfaces with conflicting MIDI channels. For example, applying a channel offset of 8 to one of the MIDI interfaces would cause that interface's channel 1 to appear as channel 9, channel 2 to appear as channel 10, and so on. This may be useful if you have multiple keyboards that are configured to use the same channel.

sect1.title: Sound Output Device
sect1.para: Provides a list of available sound output devices. Note that only one device may be used for sound output at a time. Devices are prefixed by their type, e.g. "ASIO", "DirectSound", etc.
NOTE: If an ASIO device does not appear, it may be set to an incompatible format. The control panel for the ASIO device must be set to 44.1kHz 16-bit sound.

sect1.title: Estimated Latency
sect1.para: This allows you to set a requested latency, and after you click OK or Apply, the sound system will determine tne closest feasible latency and change the value to this estimated latency. Note that the estimate is based on numbers provided by the hardware and may vary. Many ASIO devices do not allow you to change their latency except in their control panel when the device is not in use. Refer to your sound card documentation for more information. Note that use of third party drivers, such as ASIO4All, may function properly but is not supported.

sect1.title: Load Stereo Samples
sect1.para: If set to Mono, all samples are loaded in Mono. When compression is disabled, this will save 50%, but when compression is enabled, much less will be saved because the compression is much less effective on monoaural inputs.

listitem.para: Variable savings up to 50%
No impact
No impact

sect1.title: Lossless Compression
sect1.para: Uses a lossless algorithm (i.e. the original samples can be perfectly reconstructed) so that RAM requirements are lessened. Particularly useful for large sample sets.

listitem.para: Variable savings up to 40%
Approx. 10% lower
Approx. 20% slower

sect1.title: Active Polyphony Management
sect1.para: When polyphony reaches 3/4 of the current maximum value, release samples (reverberation tails) are faded out in order to conserve polyphony.

listitem.para: No impact
Conserved
No impact

sect1.title: Release Sample Phase Alignment
sect1.para: When a note is released, phase cancellation may occur as the release sample cross fades in. Selecting this option will make a best effort to phase align the release sample to help minimize this effect.

listitem.para: No impact
No impact
No impact

sect1.title: Release Sample Detachment
sect1.para: When a note is released, the tremulants or swell pedals would not normally affect the reverberation, and therefore it is highly recommended to leave this option engaged.

listitem.para: Variable savings up to 50%
Slight impact
No impact

sect1.title: Release Sample Scaling
sect1.para: For those sample sets with long reverberation tails ("wet"), enabling this option will fade out the release sample if the note is played staccato. It will have little to no effect on "dry" sample sets.

listitem.para: No impact
Slight impact
No impact

sect1.title: Randomize Pipe Speaking
sect1.para: This will apply a very small (less than 1ms) random delay before each pipe begins to speak. This may help combinations of stops to sound more natural and less repetitive.

listitem.para: No impact
No impact
No impact

chapter.para: This section will be populated once questions become frequently asked.

sect1.title: General information
sect1.para: It is an INI file in ISO-8859-1 encoding. The standard extension is .organ.
Comment lines are started with ;. Empty lines are ignored.

Various settings are grouped in block. Each block is started with a line starting with [, followed by the section name and ended with ]. Each block consists of list of name-values pairs seperated by =.

File paths in this format are relative to the location of the organ file. The directory seperator in this paths must be \. The paths should not contain /. The paths should be considered case sensitiv, even if it is not enforced on all plattforms.
Boolean values are represented as Y for true and N for false.

A color can be one of the following colors (not case sensitive): BLACK, BLUE, DARK BLUE, GREEN, DARK GREEN, CYAN, DARK CYAN, RED, DARK RED, MAGENTA, DARK MAGENTA, YELLOW, DARK YELLOW, LIGHT GREY, DARK GREY, WHITE Additionally, it supported the HTML syntax #RRGGBB
A font size can be one of the following values: SMALL, NORMAL, LARGE or a number bigger than 0.
A panel size can be one of the following values: SMALL, MEDIUM, MEDIUM LARGE, LARGE or a number bigger than 0.
The following image formats are supported: bmp, gif, jpg, ico, png

A bitmap number is a value between 1 to 64. It referes to a predefined (wood) background. An odd mumber and the following even number represent the same type of wood. The odd number has vertical grain, while the odd has horizontal grain.

Objects in GrandOrgue are eg. manuals, stops, generals, ... . Each object can consist of backend part representing the object an its configuration (eg. list of sample file names) and multiple GUI representations.
The main section is called Organ. It defines the main panel too. Objects like stops only displayed on a non-main panel need an invisible definition for the backend part on the main panel too.

sect1.title: Sample format
sect1.para: The samples are stored as WAV files according to the WAV file specification. The supported formats are: 8 bit, 16 bit and 24 bit PCM, either mono or stereo. The prefered sample rates are 44100 or 48000 Hz - GO supports any sample rate between 22000 and 96000 Hz. GO only supports a single data chunk. To play looped samples, they must include cue points (cue chunk) and loops (smpl chunk). If there are multiple loops, each loop should overlap another loop. Attack samples include the attack phase and the loops - they may contain a release too. If release samples include a cue point, the release is loaded starting with this position, else the whole file loaded. dwMIDIUnityNote and dwMIDIPitchFraction of the smpl chunk are used for retuning an organ to other temperaments.

sect1.title: Display metrics
sect1.para: The layout of any panel is described by a layout model. The available space is split vertically into three columns: The left and the right column contain a drawstops layouted via a mesh. The middle row is vertically divided:

At the bottom, the pedal and its button are placed (if present). Above, an extra row of buttons may follow. The next row contains the enclosures. Then all manuals with their associated buttons follow. The two rows are a block of buttons and pistons. The exact order can be specified via an attribute.

sect1.title: General object
sect1.para: A general object consists of a push button and a combination data store.

sect1.title: Divisional coupler objects
sect1.para: A divisional coupler is a drawstop object. If enabled, it activing a divisional on one controlled manual will acctivate the corresponding divisional on all other manuals. Additionally, it has the following attributes:

listitem.para: (boolean, required) If false, the coupler only couples upward in the manual list of the coupler, else up and downward.
(integer 1 - manual count, required) Number of manuals affected by this coupler. The list entries are stored in Manual999 setting.
(integer manual number, required) Manual affected by the coupler

sect1.title: Divisional objects
sect1.para: A divisional is a pushbutton object. Additionally, it has the following attributes:

listitem.para: (boolean, default: false) If true, the stored combination can not be changed.
(integer 0 - stop count of the manual, required) Number of stop state stored in this combination. The entries are called Stop999.
(integer 0 - coupler count of the manual, required) Number of coupler state stored in this combination. The entries are called Coupler999.
(integer 0 - tremulant count of the manual, required) Number of tremulant state stored in this combination. The entries are called Tremulant999.
(integer -manual stop count - manual stop count, required) Number of the stop. If the value is negative, it is turned off, else turned on.
(integer -999 - 999, required) Number of the coupler. If the value is negative, it is turned off, else turned on.
(integer -manual tremulant count - manual tremulant count, required) Number of the tremulant. If the value is negative, it is turned off, else turned on.

sect1.title: Manual objects
sect1.para: A manual is associated with a number of stops, tremulants, divisionals and coupler. The accessible range can be played via MIDI, the rest of the logical keys can only be triggered by (octave) coupler. It contains the following non-gui attributes:

listitem.para: (string, required) Name of the manual
(integer 1-192, required) Number of keys on this manuals (including non playable ones).
(integer 1 - NumberOfLogicalKeys, required) number of the first useable key
(integer 0 - 127, required) MIDI note number of the first MIDI acessible key.
(intger 0 - 85, required) number of MIDI accessible keys.
(integer 1-6, required) This number is used while building the initial MIDI configuration to map the manual to one midi setting from the global midi configuration dialog.
(boolean, required) If true, the manual is visible on the main panel.
(integer 0-64, required) Number of stops associated with this manual. Starting with 1, for each stop, there is a Stop999 setting.
(integer, required) Number of the Stop999 section containg the stop details.
(integer 0-16, required) Number of couplers associated with this manual. Starting with 1, for each coupler, there is a Coupler999 setting.
(integer, required) Number of the Coupler999 section containg the coupler details.
(integer 0-32, required) Number of divisionals associated with this manual. Starting with 1, for each divisional, there is a Divisional999 setting.
(integer, required) Number of the Divisional999 section containg the coupler details.
(integer 0-10, required) Number of tremulants associated with this manual. Starting with 1, for each tremulant, there is a Tremulant999 setting.
(integer, required) Number of the Tremulant999 section containg the tremulant details.

sect1.para: The various GUI manual attributes are specified for the different key types. They are named: C, Cis, D, Dis, E, F, Fis, G, Gis, A, Ais, B. If it is the first key on the manual, it is prefixed with First. If it is the last key on the manual, it is prefixed with Last. So valid values are eg. Gis, FirstDis, LastAis. In the following, these values will be marked as KEYTYPE.
If the manual is displayed, it contains the following gui attributes:

listitem.para: (integer 0 - panel width, default: according to layout model) Allow to override X position for manual.
(integer 0 - panel height, default: according to layout model) Allow to override Y position for manual.
(string, default: implementation dependend bitmap) Bitmap for the specified key type, if the key is pressed. The bitmap may contain a mask.
(string, default: implementation dependend bitmap) Bitmap for the specified key type, if the key is not pressed. The bitmap may contain a mask.
(string, default: empty string) Mask for the corresponding On bitmap. If empty, no external mask is loaded.
(string, default: corresponding on mask) Mask for the corresponding Off bitmap. If empty, no external mask is loaded.
(integer 0 - 50, default: implementation dependend) This value is added to the x position of the current key to determine the position of the next key.
(integer -50 - 50, default: implementation dependend) This value is can be used to adjust the display of the current key, eg. to place a sharp key overlapped with the previous key.
(string, default: corresponding ImageOn_KEYTYPE) Allows to set the on bitmap for the 999 key.
(string, default: corresponding ImageOff_KEYTYPE) Allows to set the off bitmap for the 999 key.
(string, default: corresponding MaskOn_KEYTYPE) Allows to set the on mask for the 999 key.
(string, default: corresponding MaskOff_KEYTYPE) Allows to set the off mask for the 999 key.
(integer 0 - 50, default: corresponding Width_KEYTYPE) Allows to set the width of the 999 key.
(integer -50 - 50, default: corresponding Offset_KEYTYPE) Allows to set the width of the 999 key.
(boolean, required) True means, the black keys are drawn in a light color while the white keys are draw dark color.
(boolean, default: false) True means, that a wood background is used for the keys.

sect1.title: Label objects
sect1.para: Lable object allow to display a text label. The background is an image. It is tiled, if the image is smaller than the label area. A label has the following attributes:

listitem.para: (boolean, default: true) True means, that the X position is determined by DispXpos, else by DispDrawstopCol and DispSpanDrawstopColToRight.
(boolean, default: true) True means, that the Y position is determined by DispYpos, else by DispAtTopOfDrawstopCol.
(integer 0-panel width, default: 0) absolute X position
(integer 0-panel height, default: 0) absolute Y position
(boolean, required if FreeYPlacement is true) If true, the lable is display above the drawstop, else below.
(integer 1- number of drawstop columns, required if FreeXPlacement is false) Position label at the specified drawstop column.
(boolean, required if FreeXPlacement is false) If true, move label half of the drawstop with right.
(color, default: black) Color for the label text.
(font size, default: normal) Size of the label font
(string, default: empty) Font for the text. Empty means use the group label font of the panel.
(string, default: empty) The text to display on this object
(integer 1-1, default: 1) Builtin bitmap set to use.
(string, default: use internal bitmap according to DispImageNum) Specifiy the file name of an image to use as bitmap. If the bitmap contains a mask for transparency, it will be used.
(string, default: empty) File name for a external mask for the bitmap. If empty, no mask is added.
(integer 0 - panel width, default: according to the definitions above) Allow to override X position for button
(integer 0 - panel height, default: according to defintions above) Allow to override Y position for button
(integer 0 - panel width, default: bitmap width) Width of the button. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - panel height, default: bitmap height) Height of the button. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - bitmap width, default: 0) X position on the bitmap of the left pixel of the button
(integer 0 - bitmap width, default: 0) Y position on the bitmap of the top pixel of the button
(integer 0 - Height, default: 0) relative X of left core of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: 0) relative Y of left core of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Width, default: Width) width of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: Height) height of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - text rectangle width, default: Width) If 0, no text is displayed. Otherwise the value specified the maximum line length used for text breaking.

sect1.title: Image objects
sect1.para: Images objects allow to display an image on a panel. They tile the images, if it is bigger then image size. It has the following attributes:

listitem.para: (string, required) Specifiy the file name of an image to use as on bitmap. If the bitmap contains a mask for transparency, it will be used.
(string, default: empty) File name for a external mask for the bitmap. If empty, no mask is added.
(integer 0 - panel width, default: 0) X coordinate of the left side. to override X position for button
(integer 0 - panel height, default: 0) Y coordinate of the left side.
(integer 0 - panel width, default: bitmap width) Width of the button. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - panel height, default: bitmap height) Height of the button. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - bitmap width, default: 0) X position on the bitmap of the left pixel of the button
(integer 0 - bitmap width, default: 0) Y position on the bitmap of the top pixel of the button

sect1.title: Button objects
sect1.para: Button objects are defined on the main panel. Their section name is based on their function. They share the following common properties:

listitem.para: (string, required) Name of the object. The name may be presented the user in lists too, therefore it should be descriptive. If a GUI representations requires a shorter name, please override this value locally.
(boolean, required) If true, the sections also includes the GUI properties for the main panel. Otherwise it is not displayed on the main panel.
(boolean, default: false) If true, off is displayed as on and on as off.
(integer 0-127, default: no MIDI event specified) Only used for building the initial configuration during the first load - provided just for HW1 compatibility.
(int 1-128, default: no MIDI event specified) Only used for building the initial configuration during the first load - provided just for HW1 compatibility.

sect1.para: The GUI properties of button objects are:

listitem.para: (boolean, default: true for divisionals, generals and pistons, else false) True means to display as button, false as drawstop
(integer 0-255, default: 0) 0 means no shortcut, else it specifies the key code of the shortcut key.
(color, default: Dark Red) Color for the label text.
(font size, default: normal) Size of the label font
(string, default: empty) Font for the text. Empty means use the control label font of the panel.
(string, default: Name of the button) Content of the text label. You should set it, if you need to display a shorter string on the label.
(boolean, default: true) If displayed as a piston and this attribute is false, move it a little bit left. Otherwise ignored.
(integer 1-2, default: 1) Builtin bitmap set to use. GrandOrgue has two for drawstops and two for pistons.
(button row, default: 1) If displayed as piston, it contains the button row according to the layout model. Otherwise ignored.
(button column, default: 1) If displayed as piston, it contains the button column according to the layout model. Otherwise ignored.
(drawstop row, default: 1) If displayed as drawstop, it contains the drawstop row according to the layout model. Otherwise ignored.
(drawstop column, default: 1) If displayed as drawstop, it contains the drawstop column according to the layout model. Otherwise ignored.
(string, default: use internal bitmap according to DispImageNum) Specifiy the file name of an image to use as on bitmap. If the bitmap contains a mask for transparency, it will be used.

(string, default: use internal bitmap according to DispImageNum) Specifiy the file name of an image to use as off bitmap. If the bitmap contains a mask for transparency, it will be used. The size must match the on bitmap.
(string, default: empty) File name for a external mask for the on bitmap. If empty, no mask is added.
(string, default: value of MaskOn) File name for a external mask for the off bitmap. If empty, no mask is added.
(integer 0 - panel width, default: according to layout model) Allow to override X position for button
(integer 0 - panel height, default: according to layout model) Allow to override Y position for button
(integer 0 - panel width, default: bitmap width) Width of the button. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - panel height, default: bitmap height) Height of the button. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - bitmap width, default: 0) X position on the bitmap of the left pixel of the button
(integer 0 - bitmap width, default: 0) Y position on the bitmap of the top pixel of the button
(integer 0 - Width, default: 0) relative X of left core of the mouse rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: 0) relative Y of left core of the mouse rectangle
(integer 0 - Width, default: Width) width of the mouse rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: Height) height of the mouse rectangle

(integer 0 - max(MouseRectHeight, MouseRectWidth), default: max(MouseRectHeight, MouseRectWidth) / 2) If 0, the mouse events are captured inside the mouse rectangle. Otherwise they must be inside a circle of the specified size too.
(integer 0 - Height, default: 0) relative X of left core of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: 0) relative Y of left core of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Width, default: Width) width of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: Height) height of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - text rectangle width, default: a little bit smaller than Width) If 0, no text is displayed. Otherwise the value specified the maximum line length used for text breaking.

sect1.para: Inside the button, the on/off bitmap (depending on the button state) is tiled. If a text width is set, a text label is displayed on it. Mouse events are only captured inside the mouse rectangle.

sect1.title: Drawstop objects
sect1.para: Drawstop objects are buttons with toogle functions. They contain these additional non-GUI properties:

listitem.para: (boolean, required) State of the button after loading.

sect1.title: Coupler objects
sect1.para: Coupler are drawstop objects. The forward key pressed from one manual to other manuals/keys. They have the following additions attributes:

listitem.para: (boolean, required) If true, this coupler decouples the manual from the stops (turn it into a floating manual).
(integer manual number, required it not a unison off coupler) manual to forwared key presses too.
(integer -24 - 24, required if not a unsion off coupler) specifies the keyboard shift between source and destionan manual in term of absolute MIDI note numbers
(boolean, required if not a unison off coupler) Triggers further inter-manual coupler with a destination key shif of zero.
(boolean, required if not a unison off coupler) Triggers further inter-manual coupler with a destination key shift greater than zero.
(boolean, required if not a unison off coupler) Triggers further inter-manual coupler with a destination key shift less than zero.
(boolean, required if not a unison off coupler) Triggers further intra-manual coupler with a destination key shift greater than zero.
(boolean, required if not a unison off coupler) Triggers further intra-manual coupler with a destination key shift less than zero.
(enumeration, default: Normal) Type of the coupler: Normal, Bass or Melody.
(integer 0-127, default: 0) first MIDI note number to forward
(integer 0-127, default: 0) number of keys to forward starting with FirstMIDINoteNumber.

sect1.title: Stop objects
sect1.para: Stop are drawstop objects. A stop consists of a number of pipes. Only the accessible pipes can be triggered from the manual. They have the following additions attributes:

listitem.para: (float 0-1000, default: 100) Linear amplitude scale factor applied to the whole stop. 100 means no change.
(float -1200-1200, default: 0) Retune the stop organ the specified number of cents.
(float 1-1024, default: 8) Harmonic number (= 64 / stop size), eg. 2 2/3 => 64 / (2 2/3) = 24.
(float -1200-1200, default: 0) Correction factor in cent for the pitch specified in the sample. This setting is used for retuning to other temperaments.
(integer 1-192, required) Number of pipes in this stop
(integer 1 - NumberOfLogicalPipes, required) The number of the first pipe accessible from the manual.
(integer 1-128, required) The key number on the manual of the first accessible pipe.
(integer 1 - NumberOfLogicalPipes, required) Number of pipes, that are playable from the manual starting from the first acessible pipe.
(interger 1 - number of windchests, required) specify the windchest, on which the pipes of the are placed.
(boolean, required) If false, the samples are played as is (without any loop/release handling)

sect1.para: The stop section contains the attributes of each of its pipes too. The attribute of each pipe are prefixed with Pipe999 (number starting with 1). The supported attributes are:

listitem.para: (boolean, default: rank percussive setting) If false, the samples are played as is (without any loop/release handling)
(float 0-1000, default: 100) Linear amplitude scale factor applied to the pipe (in addition to the organ/stop factor). 100 means no change.
(float -1200-1200, default: 0) Retune this pipe the specified number of cents (in addition to the organ/stop factor).
(string, required) Relative path to the sample WAV file of the first attack. It contain may be REF:aa:bb:cc too. In that case, it means that this pipe is borrowed from manual aa, stop bb the pipe cc.
(boolean, default: revers of percussive setting) If true, the release part is loaded from the first attack sample.

(int -1 - 1, default: -1) 1 means, that is used, if the associated wave based tremulant is on. 0 means, that it is played, if the associated wave based tremulant is off. -1 means, that it not affected by a wave based tremulant.
(int -1 - 100000, default: -1) Up to this time value in ms, the release sample is choosen. -1 means infinite.
(float 1-1024, default: rank harmonic number) Harmonic number (= 64 / stop size), eg. 2 2/3 => 64 / (2 2/3) = 24.
(float -1200-1200, default: 0) Correction factor in cent for the pitch specified in the sample. This setting is used for retuning to other temperaments.
(interger 1 - number of windchests, default: rank windchest) specify the windchest, on which this pipe is placed.
(int 0 - 100, default: 0) Number of additional attack samples
(string, required) Relative path to the sample WAV file.
(boolean, default: revers of percussive setting) If true, the release part is loaded.

(int -1 - 1, default: -1) 1 means, that is used, if the associated wave based tremulant is on. 0 means, that it is played, if the associated wave based tremulant is off. -1 means, that it not affected by a wave based tremulant.
(int -1 - 100000, default: -1) Up to this time value in ms, the release sample is choosen. -1 means infinite.
(int 0 - 100, default: 0) Number of additional release samples
(string, required) Relative path to the sample WAV file.

(int -1 - 1, default: -1) 1 means, that is used, if the associated wave based tremulant is on. 0 means, that it is played, if the associated wave based tremulant is off. -1 means, that it not affected by a wave based tremulant.
(int -1 - 100000, default: -1) Up to this time value in ms, the release sample is choosen. -1 means infinite.

sect1.title: Pushbutton objects
sect1.para: Pushbuttons are buttons without any state. It is displayed as piston.

sect1.title: Piston objects
sect1.para: A piston is a pushbutton which trigger other elements. It contains the following additional attributes:

listitem.para: (string, required) Type of the element to trigger. Value can be STOP, COUPLER or TREMULANT.
(integer first manual index - last manual index, required for stops and coupler) The manual, to which the referenced object belongs.
(integer, required) Determines the number of the object. Depending on the object it must be a valid stop/coupler number on the referenced manual or a valid global tremulant number.

sect1.title: Tremulant objects
sect1.para: Trelmulants are drawstop objects with the following additions attributes:

listitem.para: (enumeration, default: Synth) Type of the tremulant. Valid values are: Synth (synthesised tremulant) and Wave (tremulant based on different wave samples).

sect1.para: Synthesised tremulants have the following attributes:

listitem.para: (integer 32-44100, required) Period of the tremulant in ms
(integer 1-100, required) Determines the startup time of the tremulant.
(integer 1-100, required) Determines the startup time of the tremulant.
(integer 1-100, required) Determines, how much the volume will be changed.

sect1.title: Windchest objects
sect1.para: Windchest objects represent a windchest, on which pipes of stops are placed. It has the following attributes:

listitem.para: (string, default: empty string) Description of this windchest
(string, default: implementation dependend) Display name of this windchest
(integer 0 - enclosure count, required) Number of enclosures, which influnce this windchest. The list is specifed by the Enclosure999 entries in the windchest section.
(integer 0 - tremulant count, required) Number of tremulants, which influence this windchest. The list is specifed by the Tremulant999 entries in the windchest section.
(integer 1 - enclosure count, required) Number of an enclosure, which influence this windchest.
(integer 1 - tremulant count, required) Number of an tremulant, which influence this windchest.

sect1.title: Additional panels
sect1.para: It is possible to define additional panels. The section is call Panel999 with a number starting from 001. All panels use the same layout engine as the main panel, therefore the section includes all display metrics attributes. Additionally it includes the following attributes:

listitem.para: (string, required) Name of the panel
(string, default: empty) If not empty, place it in the submenu with the specified name, else directly in the panel menu.
(integer 1 - number of defined manuals) number of manuals to display on this panel
(boolean, required) Includes a manual displayed as pedal
(integer 0-999, default: 0) Number of setter elements on the panel. The section of the GUI definitions are called Panel999SetterElement999.
(integer 0 - number of defined enclosures, required) Number of enclosures on the panel. The section of the stops GUI definitions are called Panel999Enclosure999.
(valid enclosure number, required) Reference to the enclosure on the main panel.
(integer 0 - number of defined tremulants, required) Number of tremulant on the panel. The section of the tremulants GUI definitions are called Panel999Tremulant999.
(valid tremulant number, required) Reference to the tremulant on the main panel.
(integer 0 - number of defined reversible pistons, required) Number of reversible pistons on the panel. The section of the reversible pistons GUI definitions are called Panel999ReversiblePiston999.
(valid reversible piston number, required) Reference to the reversible piston on the main panel.
(integer 0 - number of defined generals, required) Number of generals on the panel. The section of the generals GUI definitions are called Panel999General999.
(valid general number, required) Reference to the general on the main panel.

(integer 0 - number of defined divisional couplers, required) Number of divisional couplers on the panel. The section of the divisional coupler GUI definitions are called Panel999DivisionalCoupler999.
(valid divisional coupler number, required) Reference to the divisional coupler on the main panel.
(valid manual number, required) Number of the manual to use a specified manual on the panel.
(integer 0-999, required) Number of stops on the panel. The section of the stops GUI definitions are called Panel999Stop999.
(valid manual number, required) Reference to the manual of the stop on the main panel.
(valid stop number, required) Reference to the stop on the main panel.
(integer 0-999, required) Number of couplers on the panel. The section of the couplers GUI definitions are called Panel999Coupler999.
(valid manual number, required) Reference to the manual of the coupler on the main panel.
(valid coupler number, required) Reference to the divisional on the main panel.
(integer 0-999, required) Number of divisionals on the panel. The section of the divisionals GUI definitions are called Panel999Divisional999.
(valid manual number, required) Reference to the manual of the divisional on the main panel.
(valid divisional number, required) Reference to the divisional on the main panel.
(integer 0-999, required) Number of labels on the panel. The section of the label GUI definitions are called Panel999Label999.
(integer 0-999, required) Number of images on the panel. The section of the label GUI definitions are called Panel999Image999.
